questions.clue: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, begins this novel by Charles Dickens.
This novel, whose first line is 'Call me Ishmael,' features Captain Ahab's obsessive quest.
George Orwell starts this dystopian novel with 'It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen.'
This novel opens with 'Mrs. Dalloway said she would buy the flowers herself,' showing a day in the life of a woman in post-WWI England.
Toni Morrison's novel begins with '124 was spiteful,' setting the stage for a haunting presence.
In 1879, this American inventor gave the world a practical electric light bulb.
In the late 15th century, Johannes Gutenberg revolutionized printing with this invention.
Patented in 1843, this invention by Sir Charles Wheatstone and Sir William Fothergill Cooke advanced communication technology.
In 1793, Eli Whitney transformed agriculture with this machine that efficiently removed seeds from cotton fiber.
Invented by Alexander Graham Bell in 1876, this device transmitted speech electrically over wires.
This river, the longest in the world, flows northward through northeastern Africa into the Mediterranean Sea.
The Amazon River, known for its vast discharge volume, runs primarily through this South American country.
This Asian river, sacred in Hinduism, is the third largest by discharge volume and supports millions of people.
Flowing through 10 countries, this river is the second-longest in Europe after the Volga.
This river, forming part of the border between the US and Mexico, is known in Mexico as Río Bravo.
Known as the 'Father of the Symphony', he composed over 100 symphonies.
Born in 1770 in Bonn, Germany, he composed the famous 'Ode to Joy'.
This Baroque composer is well known for 'The Four Seasons'.
A master of opera, some of his famous works include 'The Magic Flute' and 'Don Giovanni'.
This Romantic composer composed only nine symphonies, but his choral symphony includes a famous 'Ode to Joy'.
For 200 points: This desert mammal has elongated ears that help dissipate heat.
For 400 points: This marine mammal uses echolocation to navigate and hunt in murky waters.
For 600 points: Known for their color-changing ability, these reptiles use chromatophores to camouflage.
For 800 points: These amphibians produce a toxic secretion and have bright warning colors to deter predators.
For 1000 points: This bird uses mimicry to imitate sounds it hears, including tools and human voices.

final.clue: Despite struggling with dyslexia, this author created an imaginary world that has sold over 500 million copies since the late 1990s.
